text:
(1)

246-262 Fulton Street, west side, between Clark and Clinton Streets. The view shows at the right the establishment of Ovington Bros., sellers of Chinaware. The center building, known as a hotel was originally the Globe (1856), later the Eagle (1893), and in recent time the Commercial Hotel.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)

The same, showing more in the left foreground. Also seen in both views is the elevated structure of the B.M.T.

April 13, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

246-262 Fulton Street, west side, between Clark and Clinton Streets. The view shows at the right the establishment of Ovington Bros., sellers of Chinaware. The center building, known as a hotel was originally the Globe (1856), later the Eagle (1893), and in recent time the Commercial Hotel.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)

The same, showing more in the left foreground. Also seen in both views is the elevated structure of the B.M.T.

April 13, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Liberty Square, at the intersection of Fulton, Liberty and Tillary Streets. At the right, is the Fulton Elevated Lines of the B.M.T. on Fulton Street. At the left, is the Myrtle Ave., Elevated Lines of The B.M.T. on Tillary Street. At the right, is seen Clinton Street at Fulton Street; Also the Hotel Touraine on Clinton Street. The other tall buildings are to the south in the Borough Hall section.

June 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from another angle. The view at the right foreground, beyond the building with the "Brown Paint Co." sign was the site of the "Second Presbyterian Church" from 1831 to 1882 when it consolidated with the "Clinton Street Presbyterian Church" located at the S.E. corner of Clinton and Remsen Streets and became known as the Spencer Memorial Church (Presbyterian).

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)
Liberty Square, at the intersection of Fulton, Liberty and Tillary Streets. At the right, is the Fulton Elevated Lines of the B.M.T. on Fulton Street. At the left, is the Myrtle Ave., Elevated Lines of The B.M.T. on Tillary Street. At the right, is seen Clinton Street at Fulton Street; Also the Hotel Touraine on Clinton Street. The other tall buildings are to the south in the Borough Hall section.

June 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from another angle. The view at the right foreground, beyond the building with the "Brown Paint Co." sign was the site of the "Second Presbyterian Church" from 1831 to 1882 when it consolidated with the "Clinton Street Presbyterian Church" located at the S.E. corner of Clinton and Remsen Streets and became known as the Spencer Memorial Church (Presbyterian).

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

17-33 Clinton Street, east side, between Fulton and Pierrepont Streets. At the left, is the Hotel Touraine (No. 17). The 4 and 5-story homes, once housed the Crescent Athletic Club.
1927.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Fulton Street; west side, between Clinton (left) and Clark Streets (right) showing at the S.W. corner (right foreground) Browne's College. Also shown in the foreground, is the new park and approach to the Brooklyn Bridge, and a cut off at the right, leading to, and away from the Fulton Street Elevated Lines to a B.M.T. terminal.

April 1, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
